III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract/Policy violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included
in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
No Technical Assistance was required.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
- Staff that have been employed over a year are just hitting the 24-hour training
requirement. Consultation was provided to make sure training records for staff are
continued to be monitored throughout the year.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility had six special investigations during this period under review with one
resulting in a corrective action plan. The non-compliance included adequate staffing
on shift. The facility’s corrective action plan compliance is monitored quarterly. During
the quarterly unannounced visits, the facility has been found in compliance with
having an adequate number of staff to youth ratio. During this interim audit, this
consultant interviewed the home supervisor who reported he has been working with
his team to make sure all open staffing shifts are filled. The supervisor reported if he
does not have a staff member to fill a spot or if there is a last-minute call off, the
supervisor will cover the shift to make sure that the facility is ratio compliance. The
organization has implemented a new weekly meeting where all unit supervisors meet
to review staffing schedules and have plans in place for unexpected call ins for
coverage.
Chief Administrator Assessment:
Chief Administrator noted over this reporting period there has been a decreased
census in the program, primarily due to staffing challenges. The program has been
able to continue to maintain in ratio and continued to provide therapy and contracted
programing throughout. Wedgwood has modified the pay structure of the program
and given the largest wage increase to its workforce in years. Chief Administrator
1

notes this increase has been offset with internal costs and risks being absorbed by
the Wedgwood budget. This program has implemented additional clinical supports
thorough two full time, non-ratio counting, Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA)
staff. These staff will assist in developing and implementing behavioral plans, training
staff, providing milieu treatment therapy using a behaviorist model and tracking
effectiveness data. Chief Administrator noted staff are more motivated and beginning to
implement assigned behavioral plans on their own, restraint and aggressive interactions
are decreasing, and data is showing an improvement in client response, effect, and staff
interactions.
Interviews:
Staff and youth interviews were conducted during the inspection and no issues or
concerns were raised. The youth all reported feeling safe and had positive relationships
with staff members. The staff all reported feeling supported by direct supervisors as well
as administration. This consultant was able to interview the two new Board-Certified
Behavior Analyst (BCBA) staff that have been implemented into the West Campus team
within the past couple of months. These two staff are excited to use their learned
techniques to help support the direct care staff on the unit to care for the youth in
therapeutic ways in this specific population. The BCBA staff reported some of the veteran
staff are more resistant to this new change but have been implementing new skills on the
floor.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract and policy. It is
recommended that the facility continue on their regular license.
